did.unittitle: Manuscripts
Essay, "Some Memories of Henri Matisse" by Alice B. Toklas

scopecontent.p: [Includes cover ALS, w/env to Editor of Yale Literary Magazine. ]

did.unittitle: Essay, "The Work of Gertrude Stein" by Sherwood Anderson

scopecontent.p: [Includes autograph corrections.]

did.unittitle: Commentary of Gertrude Stein's Geography and Plays
Letters
Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Four Seas Publishing Company, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Sends him manuscript of Geography and Plays, which is going to be her fifth book, for speedy publication; says she is willing to share the production cost and awaits his suggestions and proposition; says that Sherwood Andersonis to write the preface; gives him a list of prominent people who will advertise her in Englandand France, including G. H. Wells, Roger Fry, Israel Zwangwill, Logan Pearsall Smith, Jean Cocteau, Waldman George, and Valerie Larband. ]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Says she is flattered that Brown likes the manuscript; tries to explain her method of work and how her style has developed since she wrote The Three Livesin 1905; feels fortunate to have Sherwood Anderson, a longtime admirer and student of her method, to explain her to the public; discusses the length, omissions, cost, and physical appearance of the book; suggests a royalty of 15 percent; says she will send a first payment of $1,000 toward the production.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Includes autograph corrections; says she is happy with contract; asks for minor changes; talks about translation rights and the cost of translating; encloses $1,000 towards publishing cost; speaks about the book's physical shape and the preface by Sherwood Anderson; says she will send biographical sketch and her photo by Langdon Coburnas well as the one made from her portrait by Pablo Picasso; mentions that her "Portrait of Picasso," now being translated into French, will soon appear in Jean Cocteau's new magazine.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Discusses his approval of the contract changes; suggests Curtis Brownto make arrangements for foreign publishing; mentions Sherwood Anderson's introduction of the book; tries to speed up the publishing as the book is already being talked about; mentions physical shape of book.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Includes autograph corrections; returns corrected proofs and talks about them at length; mentions physical shape of book; requests a dummy of the cover; says she will send a list of names to send circulars to; mentions photographs of herself taken by Man Rayand includes one for publicity; mentions possibility of an English edition.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Discusses corrected proofs and her definite ideas as to the looks of the book; sends list of people to whom advance notices should be sent; mentions sculpture of herself, which will be exhibited in Americain the fall, being done by Jo Davidson; considers the sculpture good publicity for her book; sends second check of $2,000.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Handwritten by Alice B. Toklas, signed by Stein; acknowledges receipt of a rough draft of the side papers; expresses definite ideas on how book should look; asks for a dummy as soon as possible.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Written by Alice B. Toklasfor Stein; discusses Geography and Plays; encloses list of people to whom review copies should be sent; gives directions; mentions reviews in Canadian papers and in the Parisedition of the Chicago Tribune; says there is interest in the book in Ireland. ]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Compliments him and herself on the wonderful book they have produced; makes suggestions which might increase sales; requests that he send a copy to Lifefor review; promises more photographs of herself by Man Ray. ]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Says she would like to know how many copies of Geography and Playshave been sold and what has been done to advance the sale; hints at a future book; gives list of names she want copies sent to; mentions newspapers which are going to do a story on her and an article by Edna Kentonabout the book; urges him to send copy to Don Marquis.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Mentions book notices and reviews; scolds him for not writing to her, failing to inform about copies sold, and not sending a receipt for a check.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Says that check and requested receipt have arrived; requests royalty statement; comments on book's success; says the interview by Jane Burrwill appear in a large syndicate of newspapers; mentions article by Mina Loyabout Geography and Plays; passes on flattering remarks about physical appearance of the book.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Complains about not having received royalty statements for January, February, and March; mentions apparent success of book.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Acknowledges receipt of statements and check covering all months up to June; encourages him to send quarterly statements from now on; says she is convinced that book sales will increase; mentions favorable newspaper clippings and that H. L. Menckenincludes her in his list of the 10 dullest authors; says Mencken's statement leaves her undaunted.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Acknowledges statement up to October; requests less tardiness with the next statement, due February 1; informs him that Ben W. Huebschis bringing out a collection of her short stories, edited by Frances Newman; says she has given Huebsch permission to include "Miss Furr and Miss Skeene"; mentions reference to her work in a story that appeared in the September Cosmopolitan. ]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Complains about errors and delays in his accounting; says she is glad about increased January sales; believes article in Atlantic Monthlywill help with sales.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Notes that all her books with the exception of Geography and Playsare out of print; wonders if he saw the laudatory article in Vogueabout Geography and Playsby Edith Sitwell; says that Sitwell's article and Mina Loy's article have been mentioned in Punch; reminds him to make sure the English agent has some copies; says statement and check are overdue.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Asks him to supply new English agent with copies of Geography and Plays; says the book has come into demand after Edith Sitwell's piece; wants him to be sure that the book is available at the principal booksellers in Oxfordand Cambridge; says that new interest in her work has arisen in England. ]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to Mrs. Harry Atwood Coleman, Washington, D. C.
Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Edmund R.] Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Discusses The Making of Americansand an overdue statement and royalty check.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, France, to Mr. Pierre de Massot, Paris

scopecontent.p: [Writes from the countryside; expresses pleasure on learning that he has written a preface for her book; comments on the weather; send greetings to his wife.]

did.unittitle: Alice B. Toklas, Paris, to M. H. Brown, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Mentions article in Axel's Castleon the work of Gertrude Stein; urges him to place an order for Lucy Church Amiably. ]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to Sir Francis Rose, Paris

scopecontent.p: [Invites him to tea the following Sunday.]

did.unittitle: Alice B. Toklas, Paris, to William Jackson, Ltd., London

scopecontent.p: [Explains for Gertrude Steinthat she has not written a book about Ernest Hemingway, but has discussed him in The Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas; informs him where the book was published.]

did.unittitle: Alice B. Toklas, The Drake Hotel, Chicago, to Georgia Lingafelt, Chicago

scopecontent.p: [Thanks her for "the delicate white violets" sent to Gertrude Stein; says that Stein hopes to find time to see Lingafelt upon her return to Chicago. ]

did.unittitle: Alice B. Toklas, Bilignin, France, to Bruce Humphries, Inc., Boston

scopecontent.p: [Asks for the long overdue statement of Geography and Plays; passes on Gertrude Stein's indignation over their ongoing tardiness.]

did.unittitle: Bruce Humphries, Inc., Boston, to Alice B. Toklas, Bilignin, France
Gertrude Stein, Paris, to Lt. Jean Deurel, Paris

scopecontent.p: [Discusses 10,000 francs paid to her by Chabot and a check sent by Deurel from Fontaine.] (In French)

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to Lt. Jean Deurel, Paris

scopecontent.p: [Discusses arrangement with Chabot for Wars I Have Seenand Three Lives; reports that her story on the Americans goes well.] (In French)

did.unittitle: Alice B. Toklas, Paris, to William S. Byler, New Haven, CT

scopecontent.p: [Discusses a piece she is supposed to write for The Yale Literary Magazineto honor Henri Matisse; explains how the rift between Gertrude Steinand Matisse came about; promises a contribution within a fortnight.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belignin par Belley, to Pierre de Massot, Paris

scopecontent.p: [Expresses delight about the preface he has done for Dix Portraits; loves his use of quotations; looks forward to the Bull-Dog; says she would like to own a lot of his writings; refers to her dog "Basket"; invites him and his wife Robbie to spend a few days with them in Bilignin. ]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belignin par Belley, to Pierre de Massot, Paris

scopecontent.p: [Invites him and [Robbie] to visit; speaks about the delightful countryside, the weather, her work.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belignin par Belley, to Pierre de Massot, Paris

scopecontent.p: [Says she greatly enjoyed his book; enjoys "actualities of 1358"; hopes to meet him in Parisnext winter.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belignin par Belley, to Pierre de Massot, [ Paris]

scopecontent.p: [Compliments him on his beautiful writing, especially [ Bull Dog]; expresses interest in his historical writings; hopes he and Mrs. Robertson will visit her.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belignin par Belley, to Pierre de Massot, Paris

scopecontent.p: [Mentions pieces he has written; renews invitation to Bilignin; mentions "Basket."]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belignin par Belley, to Pierre de Massot, Paris

scopecontent.p: [Says she has been doing interesting work and is anxious to share her ideas with him in September.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, New York, to [ Potter Palmer], [ Chicago]
Gertrude Stein, Belingninpar Belley, to Virgil Thomson, Honfleur, Calvados

scopecontent.p: [Thanks him for the "marked" copy; approves of the changes he has made; says she will send a presentation copy.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingninpar Belley, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Invites him to visit; says she is busy reading proof; describes her country place as crude, but lovely; suggests a longer visit for later.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingninpar Belley, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Says her arm is on the mend; invites him to visit; suggests he keep producing paintings and not worry about gallery politics; describes the pleasure his pictures have given a local French family who saw them at her home.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose, Paris

scopecontent.p: [Comments on his paintings; gives business advice; suggests a gallery which will put his work in a large exhibition hall; warns him not to raise his prices at this time; singles out 2 of his paintings, "the two old heads" and "the grey nude against the greenish background" as praiseworthy.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose, [Mougins], France

scopecontent.p: [Says that there is a great deal in his painting that she does not like, but she likes him, is proud of him, and has faith in him; thinks that, if he persist, he will eventually be what her letter-head, which says "Rose is a rose . . .," suggests.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose, [ Paris]

scopecontent.p: [Refuses to give one of his pictures to a gallery in exchange for another one to be chosen by the gallery; says that she bought 3 pictures from a previous show to prove her continued support, not because she was impressed.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to William Buehler Seabrook

scopecontent.p: [Expresses delight with [ The Magic Island]; finds him "simple and gay and wonderful"; walks endlessly; talks and listens to the peasants; says she is happy about all he says about her.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to William Buehler Seabrook

scopecontent.p: [Says she is pleased to have heard from him; asks him to send the book; reports on their planting potatoes, American corn and American squash; hopes to meet him again soon.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Discusses letter from Rose, which she showed to Bernard Fay, and a letter by "Waldemar"; says she met Waldemar at the gallery where Rose's pictures are on exhibit and he was impressed; advises him to let Waldermar write an article on the paintings; reports on her difficult financial situation.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Discusses Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas, photos to be used in the book and for publicity; asks about the date of his visit so they can arrange a party; says that the room has been painted and whitewashed and his paintings look lovely in it; remembers Curley, his dog.] (on "Rose is a rose . ." stationary)

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Invites him for a weekend; suggests that he stop at his place en route to see how the workmen are doing and to go back there Monday to keep an eye on everything.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Advises him to exhibit 3 paintings; suggest medicinal baths for an ailing arm; relates comments on his art by her local friends, both cultivated and not; talks about their dogs.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Cernchild], New York

scopecontent.p: [Reminisces about America; says Colette and her new husband will go to New Yorkon the Normandie's maiden voyage and will stay at the Waldorf, carrying a letter from Stein to [Cernchild]; assures him that he and Colette will like each other.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to Sir Frances Rose

scopecontent.p: [Thanks him for Christmas gift of Rembrandt drawings, which she greatly admires; mentions "Basket's" Christmas present and Rose's dogs.] (on "Rose is a rose . ." stationary)

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Reports on arrival in the country from Paris; comments on the weather, Basket's reactions to the move, etc.; looks forward to her 2 new pictures; writes about the changes she has made in hanging his pictures.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Talks about her and Alice B. Toklas' visit to the Roses and about Basket who cannot come along due to skin problems; promises that Basket will be beautiful again in the fall, to have his portrait painted.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Gives him advice on galleries; advises him not to send pictures to her as the person who used to frame the pictures is ill and she does not have anybody trustworthy to crate them to be sent back; expresses pleasure about a drawing.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Speaks about a pleasant visit with him, how they get to know each other better every time; suggests they visit St. Remytogether; knows a Chinese landscape in miniature there she wants him to paint; discusses changes in her household due to a change of landlords.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Discusses a visit from Rose put off by his illness and his dog Curley; mentions his painting "the little seven year old" which pleases her.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Complains about a recently received picture; understands why the Londonshow has been a disappointment; remembers Rose telling her that an artist has to paint bad pictures; says she is afraid he lets it turn into a habit and that she will not sponsor his New Yorkshow if his work does not improve; warns him that he is no longer young and he has to fulfill his youthful promise.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Thanks him for a picture; tells him that she likes the St. Remy as much as ever; comments on the light; tells him that she believes in him as painter.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Wonders about his well being; offers to help him in Parisif necessary; reasures him of her interest in him.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Thanks him for picture.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Says she has found a purchaser if he has a picture to sell at 300 or 400 francs; discusses dogs.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Appreciates pictures he sent her which justify her faith in him; loves one painting especially, the "new one"; talks about the quality of light in it, inner and outer light.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Discusses the placement of his work in American galleries to get the American public acquainted with him; says she will do the introduction in a catalogue for him; asks him to send her a copy of the Londonshow catalogue.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Says she has found a Londonagent, [Abdy], and gotten him interested in Rose's work; says [Abdy] would be willing to put together a Londonshow of paintings and drawings for Rose, provided Rose takes care of letter writing, appearances, etc.; states that the agents think the recent publicity Rose got from The Autobiography of Alice B. Toklaswould be of help.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Talks about his pictures; advises him to stick with Parisart dealer Pierre Collewho is the only dealer selling pictures at the moment; says she has gotten an important English collector interested in his work and that she will send Rose to Londonin the fall; mentions that Lord Berner is doing the music and the decor for one of her plays to be performed in the fall.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Discusses a landscape he wants; suggests the cascade he did at Bilignin, one of her favorite pictures; expresses pleasure with the photos of the church "Curley" sent her; invites him to dinner on the 25th.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Comments on ill health; mentions pleasure she got out of a number of his pictures.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Tells him that a letter the agent Sir Robert Abdysent him has been returned; urges him to got to post office, see what is the matter; states that the agent want to talk to Rose; sends Christmas and New Year's wishes.] (on "Rose is a rose . . ." stationary)

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to Sir Francis Rose

scopecontent.p: [Discusses pictures he sent; describes the ones he likes; says she is afraid she will miss the Chicagoshow because they will not arrive there before the 24th of March, by which time the show may be over.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Belingnin par Belley, to [ Potter Palmer], Chicago

scopecontent.p: [Discusses his possible trip to Francethat year, her upcoming lectures at Columbia University; thanks him for all he and [Harriet ?] have done for her.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to [Dr. Johnston]

scopecontent.p: [Tells him that " On Indian Bay, " in which he figures, is published in the Reviewer; hopes he likes it.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to Pierre de Massot, Paris

scopecontent.p: [Discusses a meeting with him; says she would like him to do the introduction to the "Potraits"; says she is pleased that their books came out at the same time.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to Pierre de Massot, Paris

scopecontent.p: [Hopes he is not ill; expects him at tea-time Sunday; says Bernard [Fay]will come also.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Stein, Paris, to Pierre de Massot, Paris

scopecontent.p: [Says she is pleased to have heard from him; looks forward to seeing him again.]

did.unittitle: Photographs
Magazine photo of Gertrude Stein, side view
Newspaper photo of Gertrude Stein, seated
Newspaper cut of Gertrude Stein, side view
Magazine photo of Gertrude Stein, head and shoulders
Photo of a portrait by Pablo Picassoof Gertrude Stein, seated
Miscellaneous
Gertrude Steinfor publication of Geography and Plays

scopecontent.p: [Signed.]

did.unittitle: Gertrude Steinfor publication of Geography and Plays

scopecontent.p: [Signed.]

did.unittitle: Clipping about Gertrude Stein

scopecontent.p: [Includes envelope addressed to Georgia Lingafelt. ]
